## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 304, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Mechanics 2 (M2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 787, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 322, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 539, 910, 570]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 910, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 600, 724, 615]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 615, 593, 630]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 630, 606, 645]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 658, 606, 673]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 674, 757, 689]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 689, 440, 704]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 470, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
The object has weight \(W \mathrm{N}\) and is placed with its plane circular face on a rough horizontal surface. A force of magnitude \(kW \mathrm{N}\) acting at \(30^{\circ}\) to the upward vertical is applied to the vertex of the cone. The object does not slip.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 532, 153, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 532, 740, 551]]<|/det|>
Find the greatest possible value of \(k\) for which the object does not topple.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 532, 920, 551]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 157]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.4 \mathrm{~kg}\) is projected horizontally along a smooth horizontal plane from a point \(O\). After projection the velocity of \(P\) is \(\nu \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) and its displacement from \(O\) is \(x \mathrm{m}\). A force of magnitude \(8x \mathrm{N}\) directed away from \(O\) acts on \(P\) and a force of magnitude \((2\mathrm{e}^{- x} + 4) \mathrm{N}\) opposes the motion of \(P\). One end of a light elastic string of natural length \(0.5 \mathrm{~m}\) is attached to \(O\) and the other end of the string is attached to \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 168, 156, 186]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 166, 730, 196]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\nu \frac{\mathrm{d}\nu}{\mathrm{d}x} = 20x - 10 - 5\mathrm{e}^{-x}\) before the elastic string becomes taut.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 170, 920, 189]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 485, 191, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 485, 841, 504]]<|/det|>
Given that the initial velocity of \(P\) is \(6 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\), find \(\nu\) when the string first becomes taut.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 488, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 650, 92]]<|/det|>
When the string is taut, the acceleration of \(P\) is proportional to \(\mathrm{e}^{-x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 153, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 504, 122]]<|/det|>
Find the modulus of elasticity of the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A small object is projected horizontally with speed \(V \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) from a point \(O\) above horizontal ground. At time \(t\) s after projection, the horizontal and vertically upwards displacements of the object from \(O\) are \(x \mathrm{m}\) and \(y \mathrm{m}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
Express \(x\) and \(y\) in terms of \(t\) and hence show that the equation of the path of the object is \(y = - \frac{5x^2}{V^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 180]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 156, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 500, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the greatest speed of \(P\) in the motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 84, 680, 252]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 272, 920, 323]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a uniform lamina \(ABCDEFGH\). The lamina consists of a quarter-circle \(OAB\) of radius \(r\) m, a rectangle \(DEFG\) and two isosceles right-angled triangles \(COD\) and \(GOH\). The rectangle has \(DG = EF = r\) m and \(DE = FG = x\) m.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 335, 156, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 335, 752, 354]]<|/det|>
Given that the centre of mass of the lamina is at \(O\), express \(x\) in terms of \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 336, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 84, 688, 217]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 235, 920, 319]]<|/det|>
A rough horizontal rod \(AB\) of length \(0.45 \text{m}\) rotates with constant angular velocity \(6 \text{rad s}^{-1}\) about a vertical axis through \(A\). A small ring \(R\) of mass \(0.2 \text{kg}\) can slide on the rod. A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.1 \text{kg}\) is attached to the mid-point of a light inextensible string of length \(0.6 \text{m}\). One end of the string is attached to \(R\) and the other end of the string is attached to \(B\), with angle \(RPB = 60^\circ\) (see diagram). \(R\) and \(P\) move in horizontal circles as the system rotates. \(R\) is in limiting equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 330, 156, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 330, 900, 349]]<|/det|>
Show that the tension in the portion \(PR\) of the string is \(1.66 \text{N}\), correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 345, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 633, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the coefficient of friction between the ring and the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
